A4 paper: 21.0 x 29.7 cm = 623.7 cm^2
thickness of aluminum foil: 15 - 20 μm

So an A4 sheet of typical aluminum foil will have a volume of ~ 1 cm^3
Aluminum has a density of 2.70 g/cm^3 and a molar mass of 26.98, giving roughly 4x10^25 atoms of aluminum per sheet.

Let
N: # of atoms to start with ( 4x10^25 )
x = number of cuts

N*(1 / 2)^x = number of atoms remaining

We wish there to be exactly one atom left, so

N*(1 / 2)^x = 1
(1 / 2)^x = 1 / N
- x ln(2) = - ln(N)

You would need to cut it:
x = ln(N) / ln(2) = 85 times

Starts with approx 1M of Al
N_Avogadro approx 10^23
log2/log10 approx 3.3
thus, can cut approx. 23*3.3 == 76 times.

This is much easier calculation, compared to D.Rower's, not to mention that it is impossible to cut 75.7 times ;-)

As said in another comment, this foil weighs approx 2.7 g, so it contains 0.1 mol. of aluminium, ie 6.022E+22 atoms.
Divide it by two 75 times and you'll end up with "1.6 atoms". So you still have a good chance to get 2 atoms on each side of the scissors. If you cut it once more you will eventually isolate one atom.

(1) A4 standard light duty aluminum foil
= 21.0 cm x 29.7 cm x 0.0016 cm = 0.998 cm^3 of aluminum
(2) density Aluminum = 2.70 g/cm^3
=> 0.998 cm^3 x 2.70 g/cm^3 = 2.69 g of aluminum metal
(3) atomic weight of aluminum = 26.982 g/mol Al
=> 2.69 g/(26.982 g/mol) = 0.0999 mol Al
(4) atoms per mole of Al = 6.023 x 10^23
=> 0.0999 mol x 6.023 x 10^23 g/mol = 6.015 x 10^22 atoms in A4 aluminum sheet
(5) cuts in half.
=> 2^n = 6.015 x 10^22
=> n x log(2) = log(6.015 x 10^22)
=> n = 75.7

It will require 76 cuts with a perfect cutting instrument. The later cuts will require a cutting instrument better than scissors and since the number of atoms is not formed by multiples of 2, at least one cut will not be 50/50. It would be easiest to make the very first cut of the A4 to remove the excess of 2^n atoms, rather than in half. Then cutting could be by halves down to one atom.

I think what you did was trying to create a sheet that was a square with sides equal to aluminium's atomic diameter, so you calculated the amount of times you have to cut 1 m in half to get the atomic diameter. I have tried the same approach now, and the result is ~32. Problem is that what we just did create a sheet 1 aluminium long - and 1 m wide. So you have to repeat the process. Multiplying the previous result by 2 gives us ~64.

Sheet:
1 m^2
1 layer of Aluminium (radius: 1.43 ångström)

Task:
Cut the sheet in half. Repeat untill you have a single atom.

My method:
1) Calculate the number of atoms. This is done by dividing the sheet's area with the atom's area. We get
1m^2/((1.43*10^-10m)^2*PI)
2) Each cut halves the number of atoms. In reverse we start with one atom then doubles the number untill we have the sheet.
(number of atoms)=2^x
3) Solve for x.
Using Maple 16 I get ~64.

@JDMachinima ...find the amount of atoms in the foil). The rest is just math, after cutting the foil in half n times you have (denoting the number of atoms by N, this corresponds to the latter part of the log-expression - from the comma)
N/2^n atoms
so you want to solve for n when there's only 1 atom left
N/2^n = 1
N = 2^n
log(N) = log(2^n) = n*log(2)
n = log(N)/log(2) = log(2,N)
where he uses the identity log(x^y) = y*log(x) and the notation log(x,y) = log(y)/log(x).
